projectDesc.p: "The wind stops; the dust is fragrant, and the flowers all gone" is part of The Global Medieval Sourcebook, a digital compendium of medieval texts in their original languages and in English translation. This larger project comprises computer-readable transcriptions and/or editions of texts dating from the ninth to the sixteenth century, and originating in Europe, North Africa, the Middle East, and Asia; accompanied by new English translations; high-resolution digital images of manuscript/early print sources, where available; an apparatus that includes critical introductions, textual notes and annotations; and a flexible user interface with which to navigate these materials.

editorialDecl.p: Transcriptions and translations are encoded in XML conforming to TEI (P5) guidelines. The original-language text is contained within <lem> tags and translations within <rdg> tags.

interpretation.p: Texts are translated into modern English with maximum fidelity to the original text, except where it would impair comprehension or good style. Archaisms are preserved where they do not conflict with the aesthetic of the original text. Creative translation choices are marked and discussed in the critical notes.

app.rdg: The wind stops; the dust is fragrant, and the flowers all gone.
The sun has risen high, but I am too listless to comb my hair.
Things remain the same while the people vary, and everything is over;
I am about to speak, but my tears roll down first.
I have heard that at Twin Creek the spring is still wonderful,
so I plan to go there and ride a swift boat.
I only worry that the grasshopper boat at Twin Creek
will not be able to carry so much sorrow.
